reviewText: It is true that this season is far darker, as a whole, than any other period in the run of the show.  More, the series does seem to flounder somewhat, as if searching for a direction.My contention, however, is that this foundering is exactly the point that the creators were trying to make.  Each season of Buffy has revolved around a particular theme (generally tied in with the period of life the characters are going through).  The theme for this season was described by the creators as "Oh, grow up."  The Scooby gang has put High School far behind them and now need to forge their path ahead into adulthood.  The sense of a lack of focus at this time is probably familiar to the vast majority of us who have made it past our mid-twenties.  In short, the Scoobies need to figure out what they want to be when they grow up.  This is not always fun to watch, but it arguably does more to develop the characters than any other situation the gang has faced.One note: the amazing musical episode, `Once More, With Feeling' was only aired once in its entirety (it ran over by 8 minutes in the inital airing and only the edited version has been shown since).  This DVD marks the first time that people who missed the 11/6/01 airing will be able to see the whole episode.I hate to give away plot points, so I won't go into specifics.  However, the final four episodes of the season are among the most disturbing of any show I've ever watched.  To fully appreciate this, you should have seen the five preceding seasons, and I heartily recommend that you do.  The final two episodes, in particular, are amazing.  They were shown back-to-back when they first aired, and this is a good way to watch them.  Without giving anything away, let me say that something happens near the middle of these two hours that brought literal cheers to my household.  One of those moments that makes the darkness of the preceeding hours more worthwhile.In summary, while this may not always be the most pleasant season of Buffy to watch, it is one of the most important.  If you enjoy the tearjerker episodes, you should be quite happy with many of these.  But through it all the humor is never completely lost, and when the dust settles we are left with a feeling of hope for the future of these amazing characters.
summary: It was the best of times...

reviewText: Season Six was the first season of Buffy that I didn't see on TV.  After Buffy left the WB, I didn't have cable, so I couldn't catch it on the UPN station.  I had to wait until the DVD release to see what happened in Season Six.This season hits the viewer a little hard; especially watching the episodes in rapid sequence on DVD (rather than having the week break between episodes on TV).  I felt that Season Five ended very well, and almost felt as though it could have been a series ending.  However, there was no "happily ever after" for our characters; and season Six shows us what happens after "the final battle to save the world" and the consequence of the personal sacrifices made to win that battle.  Our team has been through terrible trials, but life kept moving.  Regardless of what they've done to save the world, they still have to be able to deal with every day problems (like relationships, paying rent, etc.).Just like life, sometimes when you think the most awful thing has just happened, something worse always seems to follow it.  That seems to be the theme of this season.  Summed up poignantly in one of the last episodes, when reality unexpectedly comes tearing into this world of demons and magic and slams the viewer in the chest with a real shock.  I found many of the episodes this season to be very moving.  The episodes about addiction hit very close to home, because one of my best friends was struggling with an addiction problem at the time I was watching these DVDs.  The episodes dealing with  responsibility being forced on to a character who was finding it hard to deal with growing, brought me back to my college years struggling to stay awake in class and study during the day while cleaning dishes at a terrible restaurant at night.There is no Glory, Evil Angel, Spike and Dru, or Government Conspiracy this time around. The Season Six enemy is the self.  The struggle is with the characters realizing who they really are, and who they want to be.  It's a very introspective story.  No one changes of their own volition.  They are forced to change through circumstance.  It's a very interesting season, as far as a dramatic exercise and character exploration.  It is so dark that I can't see myself watching it over and over; yet, it is one of my favorite seasons.Don't worry, there are a lot of monsters, magic, and fighting this season as well...

reviewText: With this season, the magical carraige that was "Buffy" turned back into a pumpkin. It's no surprise, really: five years is generally the point at which a show starts to show signs of exhaustion, and while season five was a definite thumbs-up, there were a a number of sure signs of trouble to come:1) Dawn. Adding a "baby" to a family is an old sitcom device to shake things up. It worked because of the clever writing and, obviously, Michelle Trachtenberg.2) Glory. Upping the ante in the villain department every season is a good idea, but how do you top a God?3) Spike. Changing a character's basic nature from evil to good (or good to evil) is an old soap-opera trick ("What, he's good now?")4) Buffy. She died. Again. Since death is the ultimate sanction, undoing it takes the finality of death away, and stops us from caring if future characters are killed, because they can always be brought back.Season Six dealt with the problem of topping Glory by going the opposite route, and creating the Triad, three hapless nerds who in no way were worthy successors to the Master, Angelus, bad Spike & Dru, evil Faith, etc. It was often hilarious, but not really strong enough of an idea to sustain over a whole season. The Triad would have made a very funny three story arc, but beyond that, their limitations were obvious.It also made the fundamental mistake of pushing suspension of disbelief right over a cliff (that shark-headed gangster demon boss was just the worst idea in history....what were they thinking?). Also of betraying some signs of insecurity about the things they had done in season five and in six as well, and then trying to cover it up with clever humor, such as when the shrink tells Buffy that the retro-active addition of a sister (Dawn) into her alredy established family is a "ridiculous plot device" or that the Triad were "pathetic" villains. Tongue-in-cheek is one thing, farce is another. The episode where they allude that Buffy is in fact in a mental institution and everything you have seen in the previous 100 episodes is nothing more than the fever dreams of a schizo nut case is the classic "Bobby Ewing" mistake...."That last season? It was only a dream!" This was just insulting to the audience.I also felt the middle episodes suffered badly from the absence of Giles and from an overdose of Spike. Sometimes the best thing you can do with a great actor/character is hold him back a little bit, so as to leave the audience hungry. Spike is a great character and James Marsters a great actor, but sometimes less is more.This is not to say there were not some truly good moments in the season, such as Riley showing back up (didn't realize I liked this character until he left) the crotchey old Doublemeat Palace demon ("You may want to flail your limbs while you still have time"), the musical episode, the capricious and  brutally violent way that Tara is killed off, or the fact that ordinary Xander finally got to save the world when all the super-powered people failed. But overall, season six left me feeling a bit like Buffy after her ressurection: down, disappointed, and ungrateful. Five out of six ain't bad.

reviewText: 20th Century-Fox Home Entertainment has now released BUFFY, THE VAMPIRE SLAYER, Season Six, onto DVD in a 6-disc/22-episode boxed set.Though series creator Joss Whedon's special brand of humor is still present, this season's episodes have a much darker edge to them than shows in previous seasons.  Indeed, this is certainly the most compelling BUFFY season thus far.The stand-out episode is, without question, "Once More, With Feeling," a delightful one-hour Broadway-style musical in which the entire cast either sings or dances.  Then, there's "Normal Again," which places Buffy in an alternate reality.  It's a great premise which, in this writer's opinion, should have been the basis for the series finale.Since Buffy (Sarah Michelle Gellar) "died" at the end of Season Five, the initial episodes of this season deal with her resurrection, courtesy of a black magic spell cast by best friend Willow (Alyson Hannigan).Buffy's back, but there's something different about her.  It's so different that she even begins a torrid affair with nasty, albeit psychologically neutered, vampire Spike (James Marsters).  Additionally, Buffy is forced by a lack of finances to get a low level job and also has to deal with the fact that that sister Dawn (Michelle Trachtenberg), has become a shoplifter.Xander (Nicholas Brendon) and his former-demon girl friend, Anya (Emma Caulfield) continue their romance to a heart-breaking climax in the "Hell's Bells" episode, and Giles (Anthony Stewart Head) spends much of the season back in England.The chief villains this season are three geeks who have caused Buffy problems in previous seasons and have now decided to become the crime lords of Sunnydale.  Sadly, their moronic schemes result in multiple tragedies, causing a grief-stricken Willow to try to destroy the world via black magic.Among the many DVD extras is the A&E; series overview. reviewText: By the time season five ended, we had witnessed the second best season of the entire show. With Buffy dead, and the show moving to a new network, the skepticism definately began to settle in for the future of the show. However, even though Buffy may have died at the end of the previous season, the momentum of the show was still very much alive. Season 6 moves at a different pace than the previous seasons because it relies on the characters to bring themselves down, and less on a major villan like Angelus, The Mayor, or Glory. This is perhaps what made season 6 feel like such a refreshing change of pace.The sixth season of Buffy the Vampire Slayer was a much darker season however. You see everything from Spike and Buffy in a violent relationship to Willow turning evil. But, there are some light hearted elements that manage to break some of the overall tension like the geeky group called "The Trio" which make it their mission to take care of Buffy using "brains over braun". The group is made up ofWarren - who created the Buffy bot in season 5, Johnathan - who was the nerd of focus while the show was in high school, and a newcomer more nerdy than both of them put together named Andrew (whose sexual preference is in constant question throughout the show).The third and fifth seasons may have been better overall, but season 6 is highly underrated and extremely enjoyable in my opinion. The episode that has gained the most attention is "Once More with Feeling" which is basically a musical with some dialogue mixed in. All the actors did a good job and supplied their own voices for the episode. What amazed me was the fact that everyone from Sarah Michelle Gellar to James Marsters can actually sing. Other episodes worth mentioning are "Normal Again" , "Tabula Rusa", "Seeing Red", and the final three episodes - "Villans", "Two to Go", and "Grave" which brought season 6 to an extremely satisfying close.Overall, the sixth season of Buffy the Vampire Slayer is definately worth watching and one of the more enjoyable seasons of the show. The DVD set for season 6 is great as well. My favorite aspect was the in-depth featurette "Buffy the Vampire Slayer : Television with a Bite" from A&E.; Tons of great information about the whole show. You also get the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences panel discussion, outtakes, and more.A solid 5 stars....

reviewText: My incapacitating new-found obsession with this all-consuming thing known as "Buffy The Vampire Slayer" continues with the sixth season box set.As a proud newbie, I am devouring the seven seasons on DVD as quickly as I can grab a few minutes in front of a TV.I tend to agree in part with many of the comments listed below. There are whole strings of episodes which fully blow. Some of the worst Buffy hours are here in the this season, and it's a little...but only minimally and at it's worst temporarily...disappointing. There are shows that are so joyless, so dark, so depressing...yes it may be "art", it may be "real" but it was also no fun.You will find yourself saying "what happened to the funny?" The resurrection of Buffy...heck, the whole first half year...is just tough on a Buffy fan.Except...and it is these sort of thoughts which elevate this season to miraculous heights...when you least expect it, Whedon and company throw you a big ol' Bugs Bunny curve. The first one being the musical episode. Dear God in heaven, in the midst of a sour beginning to a painful season, there is this soaring piece of work that will, in my usual hyperbolic manner, lift your soul.Yeah yeah yeah. You'll laugh, you'll cry...whatever. You will.Again, like so many single episodes of this amazing series, it stands out as one of the best hours of television. Ever. No hyperbole there. Fact. Put this, and "Hush", and maybe a half dozen other episodes against anything you've ever seen on the small screen, and they hold up.After a agonizing mid-season quality lull (but being honest, hardly ever really boring...), the conclusion to the year...the last four or five hours...are transcendant.Xander & Anya's courtship continues towards the standard TV-series wedding-day episode that is acutely observant in certain domestic issues you hadn't yet seen on "Buffy". And Nicholas Brendon does an exemplary job here.Willow's magic-as-drug addiction/recovery plotline does wear thin, and is a little too obvious, yet her "Dark Phoenix" conversion still remains chilling. Viewers have grown to love Willow, and seeing this beyond-evil manifestation makes you wish out loud she doesn't succumb to her "dark side."Dawn's a bit weak this year. But I didn't find her as non-intentionally irritating as some other reviewers out there, if that means anything.I loved the three nerd villains, but probably only because I understood WAY too many of their in-jokes.The whole Buffy/Spike thing left me cold for most of the year. I didn't "see" it. I didn't "feel" it, I guess.It felt a little forced...but when it reaches that violent twist in her bathroom, I was seriously disturbed. Maybe I DID feel it...hmmm.Rest assured, the creators still have a way of shocking and surprising even the most jaded and experienced viewers. Twice in the last three episodes (the last during the final millisecond of the entire season) I was utterly shocked...flabbergasted...blown out of my chair.Once, I even stood up and said out loud to my television set, "No WAY!"But, as you may imagine, I put an expletive between those two words.I was masterfully led in one direction, and found myself in a place I didn't expect, yet it made perfect sense.I willingly lose sleep to watch this show. As a busy vascular and trauma surgeon, there's really no higher praise.
summary: I willingly forego sleep to watch this show.

reviewText: Its difficult to judge this season of Buffy. After all it had all the hallmarks of being one of the best. There was multiple main character deaths, plenty of original storylines, an interesting villian. It really had promise. And yet...it didnt quite hit the mark.For some reason the soul seemed to vanish with this season. This may have been intentional on the creators part, but for some reason this viewer was left a little cold.For starters the character of Buffy became even more unlikeable for me. Her death brought about a kind of vacuousness that was only ever so slightly present before. Xander, once a wonderful and funny character, began his slow descent into nothingness. Dawn continued her pointless presence. And Willows so called increased power just seemed rushed and out of place(though admittedly quite cool towards the end).The one saving grace for me, as it has always been, is Spike. His character has always remained fresh and interesting. Even in this season where he endures countless acts of humilation at the hand of a very heartless Buffy, Spike retains his dignity. (This is disregarding the episode of "Seeing Red", which I have since learned was nothing but a last minute ploy to get Spikes character out of Sunnydale and into a new soul.)Of course this season had its highlights. "Once More With Feeling" is an amazing triumph. The songs are wonderful and brilliantly sung by the cast. I enjoyed Amber Bensons contribution most of all. I also like "Wrecked" and "Smashed" if only for the gratuitous nudity of a certain Mr. James Marsters;-}"The Body" has a kind of eery powerful charm that leaves the viewer very unsettled. And the final two episodes are memorable, particulary for the dialogue between Willow and Buffy before their big showdown. Plus I did enjoy most of the early Nerds scenes. Andrew and Jonathan retained a kind of warped sweetness even when trying to be "Crimelords", that made you feel very conflicted over whether you should care what happened to them.I suppose this season seems like such a departure from the others because of the fact that the emotions of the characters achieve dominance over the action for a change. This results in an entirely different tone to the previous seasons. There is a disjointed structure in the narrative for example. One episode would deal with something important and then the next would disregard it completely. Our main villians are infact nothing more than red herrings and we lose the important characters of Joyce and Tara. The viewer suffers a lot of changes and upheavals, and unfortunately it doesnt really pay off. Not to say that all stories should have a happy ending but after such an amount of grinding misery it would help a little.Even dispite its change of pace and noticible lack of humour, season six maintains a certain level of distinction for experimenting with an already winning formula. It is quite fearless in taking these well established characters and situations down an new and much darker road and for that it should be given credit.

reviewText: Buffy Season 6 was probably my least favorite season. reviewText: The most obvious thing to state about Season 6 of Buffy is that a lot of fans hate it, whilst there's a core group who defend it with their lives.  Personally, Season 6 is perhaps the most ambitious season of any TV show in history.  Moving the characters from out of the safe college settings and splitting them up to inflict the depression and monotony of adult life was a brave decision by Joss Whedon.  Among the various story arcs there's Buffy's abusive relationship with Spike, the most complex and interesting relationship the show's had.  Hating Spike, hating herself, Buffy goes into freefall.  There's also the badly handled drugs metaphor of Willow's 'addiction' to magic, which was thankfully partly rectified in Season 7; Xander and Anya drift into a marriage, into adulthood, before Xander decides he's not ready, and Dawn is neglected by the family that's supposed to support her.My first defence of Season 6 would be that whilst admitedly some writers didn't seem to 'get' Whedon's vision for the year (and it's notable that he wasn't around as much), many did, and Season 6 offers up some of the show's best ever moments.  The most obvious, tellingly the only one in the series written by Whedon, was the musical episode Once More With Feeling.  This blew self-indulgent attempts at musical episodes from the likes of Xena and Ally McBeal out of the water.  Not only is each song catchy, hummable, borrowing from a wide variety of sources, but each one is required to eke out the pain, heartbreak or love of characters that feel too emotionally clammed up to talk normally about their feelings rationally.  Plus, Giles and Tara's duet is sublime.  Bargaining Part 1 is probably the best season opener, which set up the darker themes of the season from the get-go.  Dead Things is the single most dark episode the show's ever done (with the possible exception of Lies My Parents Told Me), with Buffy and Spike's relationship coming around on itself as Buffy desire to 'feel' turns inwards on itself in a brilliantly conceived, and very creepy dream sequence.  The big story of the season though, was the death of Tara by geek-turned-murderer Warren accidentally shoot her through her bedroom window.  Though a lot of people have complained that this is some kind of anti-gay comment by Whedon, it's clear to anyone who actually watches the show that this couldn't be any further from the truth.  The hideously unexpected death serves to push Willow over the edge in a spiral of despair and hopelessness that grips you like the show's never gripped you before.  Though Grave is a bit too sentimental, the fact that destroying the world seems to be the only solution to Willow's misery seems appropriate.Unfortunately, Season 6 was marred by a few sub-standard episodes.  Doublemeat Palace of course springs to mind, though Flooded, Life Serial and Hell's Bells never really fulfilled their potential and displayed soapier elements of the show that didn't really work.  In spite of this though, we get to see Sarah Michelle Gellar's best acting to date as her character is fleshed out to become a genuinely complicated and increasingly interesting character.  Her acting in Seeing Red, Once More With Feeling, Afterlife and Normal Again is Emmy-worthy, though predictably it wasn't recognised.Whilst Season 6 wasn't as good as Season 5 it's still an immensely brave and interesting piece of television that will be remembered in years to come as Buffy's more experimental period.  To really appreciate it though you've got to ask yourself whether any other show around could go to places as dark as Season 6 did?  Well worth owning.

I was deeply moved by his reaction to Buffys resurrection and how subtly he played it.Of the episodes that were tops in this season, ONCE MORE WITH FEELING tops the list (the music was so stuck in my head I had to buy the sountrack CD!) reviewText: Contrary to most fans of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, I find the controversial sixth season to be the best of the series.  Much darker and maybe even a little meaner than previous seasons, the sixth season of Buffy was the first season to be broadcast on UPN (after the series' move from the WB) and showed the gang we know and love taking on their toughest opponent yet: life.  Beginning with Willow (Alyson Hannigan), Xander (Nicholas Brendon), Anya (Emma Caulfield), and Tara (Amber Benson) raising Buffy (Sarah Michelle Gellar) from the dead, we find Buffy going through the motions since she was torn from her heavenly bliss.  She begins a secret and dangerous affair with vampire Spike (James Marsters) while fighting to keep her sister Dawn (Michelle Trachtenberg) from being taken away by social services.  Willow gets drawn deeper and deeper into the addicting darkness of magic, while Xander and Anya rush towards marriage without ever bringing up each other's hesitations.  But there's more going on as well.  Three of their high school contemporaries: Warren (Adam Busch), Jonathan (Danny Strong), and Andrew (Tom Lenk) have taken a criminal turn using magic which begins with petty theft and escalates into murder, ending in the death of Tara and Willow's apocalyptic revenge which threatens the world.  Standout episodes include the ever popular and fantasticly produced "Once More With Feeling" in which the entire town of Sunnydale is under the spell of a song and dance demon and features the entire cast singing with their own voices like a musical number, while "Hell's Bells" becomes a pivotal episode as the marriage between Xander and Anya goes up in smoke.  In my opinion, season six of Buffy is undoubtadly the best season of the series because it shows the gang more or less going through real, tough life situations that we can't avoid, and by the season's end we are left with a consoling note and feeling of redemption; something that the show richly deserved.
summary: The best season of Buffy bar none

reviewText: This long review contains numerous spoilers.Season six is one of the darker seasons of Buffy, especially in its first two thirds. Its ending fails to completely satisfy, as Willow is not a very impressive Big Bad. The trio of evil nerds is just not good, period, with the partial exception of the underused Andrew. However, it is the season of Buffy + Spike together, the season where Buffy is forced (by Giles and by circumstance) to really stand up for herself and be an adult and take responsibility for herself and her sister. And what's interesting is that she doesn't precisely succeed.The season begins with a disorienting feeling. Buffy has been dead for five months, having sacrificed herself to save Dawn. The Scoobies are struggling to cover for her absence, using the Buffy-bot to make up for the lack of a real Slayer. With Faith still in prison but alive and thus not replaced, there is no Slayer in Sunnydale, but the denizens of the Hellmouth can't be allowed to know that.Things aren't going much better on the personal front. Willow and Tara have moved into the Summers home to care for Dawn (and to avoid paying rent?) But there's no long-term planning going on as to how the gang will get by financially and otherwise without the Slayer. Everything is a stopgap solution.So the Scoobies, led by Willow, decide that they need to bring back Buffy. They know that the rift she dived into at the end of season five may have led to a very dark place, and they're worried that Buffy may be suffering in some hell dimension as Angel once did for centuries.So Willow casts a spell to bring Buffy back. Only they haven't rescued her from hell, they've yanked her out of heaven and back into the world. To Buffy, who had been at peace where she was, her reentrance to the world is the true hell. But she can't let Willow and Dawn and the others know that. Only to Spike does she reveal the depth of her despair.Spike is still in love with Buffy. He knows to the day exactly how long she's been gone. It's agony for him to hear the Buffy-bot recite any of its admiring phrases. When the real Buffy returns, her feeling of emptiness leads her to turn to him and use him. Not for love, but for solace, and to forget for a little while. She also seems to have lost confidence in herself, and following Giles's departure to England, she needs something to fill the void in her life.Meanwhile, the responsibilities she should be dealing with but can't bring herself to face are piling up. The Summerses have big money problems (wouldn't Joyce have had some insurance? And didn't she own an art gallery?) which among them Giles and Willow and Tara seem to have ignored. Willow and Tara don't seem to pay rent or anything, which might keep Buffy from having to be the only one who works. Dawn has been neglected and is acting out by stealing trinkets, including many from the Magic Box. When Anya finds this last out, she is justifiably furious at Dawn's betrayal of her friendship.Buffy + Spike is not a pretty couple to watch. He genuinely loves her, yet he treats her like trash (probably a product of him still being a soulless demon who loves her as well as it's possible for him to, not to mention his having experienced a century of love/hurt patterning with the insane Dru). Buffy doesn't love Spike, but she uses him nonetheless. When she finally does the right thing and breaks it off for his sake, he can't handle it and tries to rape her. Of all the wonderfully "wrong" couples in the Buffyverse, Buffy + Spike may be the best pairing, though the attempted rape of course leaves a bad taste. But everything up to then was great.The events leading up to the beginning of their actual sexual relationship are perhaps even more gripping than the affair itself. A clearly conflicted Buffy will kiss Spike, then later deny that it had meant anything, then kiss him again. Spike doesn't precisely woo Buffy in the traditional sense. For one thing, he punches her in the jaw an awful lot for a hopeful suitor - which we can accept because we know she's a lot stronger than he is.And there's a method to Spike's madness. One of the emotional high marks of the season comes when a triumphant Spike demonstrates to Buffy that he can now hit her without feeling any pain from his brain chip, which normally punishes him for hurting humans. He gleefully explains to a confused Buffy what it must mean: "Don't you see? You came back WRONG!" Buffy's fear that he must be right, that she is not the same Buffy who had died but just a counterfeit that isn't even human, undoubtedly plays a large part in her submitting to him sexually.Spike's season ends with him determined to rid himself of his chip. He is tired of being a weakling in love with a Slayer, and tired of not being able to do anything about it. He travels to Africa and thinks he has made a bargain to achieve his goal.A big disappointment in this season is the diminution of Dawn's importance and screen time. Although the season begins where season five had left off as far as the endearingly inappropriate friendship between Spike and Dawn is concerned, this aspect of the characters' lives fades as the season progresses. Perhaps the show's writers thought it would be unfair to Dawn to still have her palling around with Spike after his intense affair with Buffy had begun.Dawn is no longer the key, but she should still be important as a character and as Buffy's only remaining family. Instead, she becomes a klepto for no particular reason and she and Xander and Anya are pushed to the side in favor of Willow.This is the one true flaw of season six, the inflation of Willow's importance at the expense of everyone else. For one thing, I think the show needed a better balance of female and male protagonists, as it had in fact enjoyed during its glory years of the first three seasons. Making Willow practically a co-lead of Buffy's exacerbated the sexual imbalance. It's not a romance or sex thing: just a recognition that most viewers like to see both female and male characters. With Buffy naturally occupying the main position, what the show needed was a stronger presence of Xander and/or Spike, not of Willow.But the main problem with Willow is that neither the character nor the actress is up to part of carrying entire story arcs or season plotlines. The whole point of the Scoobies was always just that: that they were Buffy's supporters - her "minions," as it were. Making Willow far stronger than Buffy (or anyone else), negates the focus of the entire show. Buffy had might as well run off to Rome right now and hit the disco with that Immortal guy. She doesn't have the power to confront Willow, or to significantly aid her.Within the limits of her very modest abilities, Alyson Hannigan was acceptable as Willow because of what the character originally was and wasn't. She was loyal and studious and good-natured. She wasn't sexy or exciting or dramatic or funny. She had never been believable as a brainiac because the actress was clearly in way over her head exchanging repartee with the far more talented Gellar, Brendon, Carpenter, Caulfield, Seth Green, etc. In the early years, it was often painful to watch those actors whip the verbal ball around professionally and then pause politely while Hannigan slowly recited the Willow speeches in her little girl voice.Unfortunately, nothing has really changed since then except for what they're asking of Willow, which is far more than she/Hannigan can provide. Mousy little Willow wearing black contacts isn't a terrifying elemental force - she's still just mousy little Willow and always will be. Making her like girls instead of boys didn't make her any sexier. Now she just has a dull schoolgirl relationship with Tara instead of with Oz.Actually, the Willow character had gone through so many conventional "rebellions" in seasons four though six, she was already a walking cliché. We've all met too many "individualists" like Willow. You could set your watch by the utter predictability of her latest phase: "Hey, I changed my hair! Hey, now I'm a Wicca! Hey, this week I'm a lesbian! Hey, Gaia!" I suppose I missed the episode where we were lectured about becoming Vegans. She was the poster girl for posers adopting lifestyles as fads. For years I really thought they were setting her up to be smacked down. Maybe that was the original intent. It's hard to believe the show's producers could always have been that humorlessly earnest about such a cardboard rebel.Did I mention I'm not a huge Willow fan anymore? Anyway, in season six she is turned into an out and out jerk, which is far worse and less interesting than if they'd made her a believable threat. The one thing that does come through believably when she's mocking Dawn and then trying to actually harm her is that Willow envies Buffy and resents her friend's accomplishments.I actually found this convincing on a human level. It wouldn't be easy being an anonymous Scooby to the Great Chosen Slayer who is loved and/or feared by all - especially if it turned out you were in actuality far stronger than Buffy. A problem I have with this concept though is that the show never really deals with it, either this season or next. The assumption everyone operates under is that anything bad Willow does is wholly attributable to her addiction to dark magic. It's apparently not the true Willow saying and doing all these mean things, so she gets a free pass for all of them. Forgiveness is all well and good, but Willow seems to automatically be granted it without deserving or even asking for it.Most problematic is the way Buffy repeatedly leaves Dawn in harm's way all the while knowing that Willow is a stick of dynamite waiting to go off. Dawn repeatedly pays the price (or almost does) of Buffy's negligence. Dawn would be safer in Spike's crypt than she is with Time Bomb Willow.And the entire end of the season was unbelievable even within the context of the show. Willow's going to destroy the whole world because Tara died? But she stops because Xander is still her friend? The first idea is unlikely, but once someone makes a decision like that, I don't think Xander blathering on about the good old days of attending kindergarten together is going to change her mind.As for the trio, yes they're lame, and no they're not very funny, except for Andrew at times and very occasionally Jonathan. But they are emphasized in the reverse order of their appeal, and it is obnoxious Warren who is the main nerd. They don't really have any reason to be taking on Buffy (and in Jonathan's case, he's actually being an ingrate in doing so, as she bailed him out more than once in high school). Why not just move to another town instead of plotting to annoy Buffy? It's just mischief for mischief's sake, which isn't very scientific. And we can't really be too amused by them after Warren kills his ex-girlfriend and the others help him cover up. When there are unlikable characters who aren't even competent bad guys, it's hard to justify using as much screen time on them as the trio was given.When things go badly for Warren, it is neither with science nor magic that he reacts but with gunfire. He almost kills Buffy and does kill Tara (though the angle of that shot, which passed through the window and then into Tara's back, is all wrong considering where Warren fired from in the back yard). This tragedy of course is what precipitates Dark Willow's metamorphosis into Evil Willow.Unfortunately, Tara's death just doesn't resonate the way Joyce's or even Jenny Calendar's did. I think the problem was that Tara was never fully fleshed out. She wasn't given any real flaws or personal idiosyncrasies, either normal human ones or esoteric witchly ones like Willow's. She was basically a paragon of patience and prudence and good humor, which is no doubt all very commendable but is also boring and unbelievable. After she died, I realized that the reason I just didn't care is that the character had never seemed alive to begin with.Xander and Anya had long before entered the boredom zone as a couple. I suppose the show's writers felt as much too, and decided that the way to rekindle interest in them was to break them up rather than marry them. The operation was a qualified success. It at least put them both back into play, even if Xander had to come off as hopelessly immature as the price. Their abortive wedding was a great showcase for Spike to ostentatiously bring his loser date to so as to make Buffy jealous. However, the entire plot of Xander's family clashing with Anya's demon friends was ridiculous.Riley returns briefly, happily married to a fellow demon fighter in the special forces. This provided totally unneeded closure to a storyline and character that never should have existed in the first place. Of course the real effect of Riley's return is to highlight to Buffy how empty her life now is.I thought I was going to hate Once More with Feeling when I realized it was a musical. But the episode is a great musical for people who don't care for musicals. True, some of the major leads can barely carry a tune (especially Nicholas Brendon and Sarah Michelle Gellar), and it was left to Giles, Anya, Spike, and Tara to carry the singing load. But the episode wasn't really about singing, it was about revelation. Under the power of the musical spell, Buffy reveals to her friends what she had never wanted to tell them: that instead of saving her from hell, they had pulled her out of heaven. And of course the episode ends with Buffy's and Spike's first kiss.The follow-up episode, Tabula Rasa, is almost as important and revealing. It follows a long-established Buffy pattern of ending a seemingly lighthearted MOTW episode with an emotional bombshell: in this case, Tara's realization that Willow has been magically tampering with her memory. Even Willow realizes that this time she's gone too far to be forgiven. The amnesia plot of the episode itself could have been a failure, but the actors and characters make it work, particularly Spike, Giles, and Anya. Giles was especially good in believing that he was Anya's fiancé and Spike's disapproving father. And the references to Angel, when Buffy and Spike realize that Spike is a vampire - "I'm atoning for my sins. I'm the vampire with a soul; I help the helpless!" - are hilarious, especially when Buffy scoffs at the absurdity of the concept.The best storyline of the season was of course the Buffy + Spike pairing, and as their affair tailed off, so did the season's ability to entertain. Willow's pursuit of vengeance was a poor substitute for Buffy's pursuit of oblivion via Spike. I've said before and I'll say again that when Buffy (and Angel) were successful at making viewers care about the fates of their characters, it was always on an individual level and not a global one. It is possible to believe and fear that Angel will hurt Buffy, that something bad will happen to Joyce or Dawn, that Xander will be maimed, etc. It is possible to fear that in her grief Willow might pursue vengeance too far and do something irreversible that will in turn blight her for life.But it is not really possible for viewers to fear that Willow will destroy the world. The big apocalypses are personally unmoving. It is the credible events affecting individual people that can grip us. When Buffy remembered this fact, it had a real emotional impact. When it forgot this, when the threat became worldwide, then the show lost the ability to truly impact its audience.I place season six in the middle, stronger than one, four, and seven, but not up at the level of two, three, or five. It is indeed one of the darkest years, along with two and five. The darkness is particularly effective in that it comes from within. As wrenching as Angel's betrayal of Buffy had been in season two, that was still an external force that didn't threaten who Buffy was. It was just a very bad thing happening to her. The darkness of season six is a Buffy darkness, made all the worse by the fact that Buffy can't share it with her friends, except for some with Spike. As far as Willow and Xander and Dawn are concerned, everything's super and they've saved the day.The season has more hits than misses, though I wish the writers had let the "Big Bad" be Buffy's self-loathing and self-doubt themselves, rather than the three stooges or Goth Willow. Buffy's true enemy this season was Buffy, and more could have been built on that theme.

reviewText: Creator of Buffy, Joss Whedon, sure knows how to pull the rug out from under you. Just when you think "oh a hell-god as the big bad (from the previous season)they can't top THAT!' Whedon does.Life is the big bad! Buffy gets into some things this season that some viewers might think is heaps dodgy and unlike her character. However in the epic storyline that travels from season 1 through to 7 this season was completely necessary in the growth of the characters.And don't worry the season finale has a big battle, just as with the previous seasons.Over the season Buffy, Xander, Willow, and the gang learn that they've all become grown ups and have to deal with scary adult stuff. This is where season 6's similarity with season 3 comes in. In season 3 growing up and being in high school was freaky and amplified by the fact that it all happened for the scooby gang on a hellmouth. Season 6 is much the same but instead of thinking of their future careers and surviving high school the gang must survive life. Buffy deals with bills, Xander and Anya deal with getting married, while Willow deals with her future as a witch.Meanwhile as this arc continues throughout the season the writers of "Buffy" are consistent in creating "oners" (episodes that don't necessarily link with the rest of the season); monster-of-the-week episodes.One such episode is the musical, "Once More With Feeling", which allows fans and new viewers alike to enjoy. reviewText: This is easily the most controversial season of Buffy.  While it garners a favorable four and a half star average rating here, the Buffy fan community at large looks on this season with much contempt. Having read through the other 400 reviews before typing this one, one thing I've seen a lot of is the season six lovers attacking the season six bashers, saying basically 'you just didn't like it or didn't get it because the season was too dark and mature for you!' I like dark and mature subject matter just fine.  In fact, I'm more of an Angel fan than a Buffy fan.  Angel, the darker, more mature spinoff from Buffy is the superior show. Buffy has gone to dark, mature places before.  The second half of Season two is a prime example.  I think I can safely speak on behalf of the Buffy fans who disliked season six that; we don't dislike it because it was too dark and mature, we dislike it because it was a poor lackluster season compared to the earlier seasons of the show.  The show used to tell stories with complex metaphors.  This season it was pretty much Buffy has raunchy sex with Spike a lot. Wait, I must be one of those fans who just hate seasons four and six right?  Nope, loved season four, don't like five.  Hence the title of my review.  The show started going down hill in season five. You can't put all the season six bashers neatly into that often discussed category. It was an incredibly depressing season.  Buffy is depressed because she was resurrected after being pulled out of heaven.  Okay, I'll buy that.  But all the charcter's were in depressing places in their lives this season.  This season, the show made an attempt to convey the harsh realities of real grown up life on the characters.  But they layed on the reality too thick.  Buffy trying to make ends meet by flipping burgers at a fast food joint isn't interesting drama on a fantasy show. What happened to the metaphors?  Oh yes, there was the weak 'Willow is a addicted to magic' drug metaphor we could have done without.  And how can we forget the major annoyance factor this season in the continuing presence of Dawn. I said it in my season five review, I'll repeat it here; they should have killed Dawn rather than Buffy in the season five finale.  Buffy's loss of her sister would have made for some good but not over the top angst in season six, and Dawn not being around to drag the show down further would be a major boost.All that being said, there were some good moments, and I like this season better than season five.  Most notably where Willow becomes evil in the last four episodes. We could have done without the magic/drug metaphor all season, the death of Tara alone would trigger Willow's descent into dark magic, but once it happens, watching Willow, the shy, sweet, computer nerd from season one become the ultimate villain is a sight to behold.  Alyson Hannigan plays it beautifully, no surprise she's the most talented member of the main cast.  Dark Willow and Buffy face off before the fight, Buffy gives a pompous speech about showing her what a slayer is, to which Dark Willow replies "Ah Buffy, you really need to have every square inch of your ass kicked." No doubt, one of the best lines in the series. Then an awesome fight scene ensues.If you've never watched a season of Buffy before, don't start here.  If you are a fan of earlier seasons of the show, I can't recommend this season.  I can only recommend it to fans who have already seen most of the episodes in first run or reruns and know what they are getting, or the completist fan division who like to have every episode of a series. This season is still notably better than most of what's on televison.  But Buffy's best days are gone.

reviewText: The above quote, sung in the musical episode of this season of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" is possibly the lightest point in the entire show. With episode titles such as "Wrecked", "Smashed" and "Grave", this is certainly the darkest chapter in the Buffy saga.  Last season's finale left us after Buffy had sacrificed herself to save her sister, her friends and the world, and that seemed to be the end of the Slayer. But a summer later, powerful witch Willow has discovered a plan to resurrect her best friend and the guardian of Sunnydale's hellmouth.But things are never that simple, and soon it is revealed that they have forcefully ripped Buffy out of Heaven, and in comparison her life on earth is painful and hellish. With Dawn to look after and bills to pay, Buffy is forced to get a full-time job between her nightly patrols. Whilst Xander and Anya plan their wedding, and Willow steadily falls prey to the intoxicating power of magic, Buffy finds herself spending more and more time with Spike...And on top of all this, three familiar faces from high school are trying their hand at villainy, eventually going from annoying to deadly foes.Season six was just as much Willow's show as it was Buffy's, and for the first time in the show a secondary character steps up to take a place of equal power and significance to Buffy herself. Moving from her normal, chirpy self to a dark and formidable opponent, and all the places in between these two extremes, Alyson Hannigan takes her character to levels that have been building since early episodes in which she first began dabbling with magic. Eventually her progression is taken full circle, especially in regards to her relationship with Xander.Can I share a pet peeve? Season six would have been the ideal opportunity to bring back Hank Summers, the girls' father, one of the most under-used characters in the Buffy-verse. He had previously been established as an absent, but loving father, but now due to his complete absence he comes across as horribly neglectful. What parent leaves their 20 and 15 year old daughters to fend for themselves? His presence would have added stability to the girls' lives, as well as a new spanner in the works and nostalgia as Buffy attempts to hide her calling from him. He could even have been used as a reason to why Giles left (sorry, but I didn't buy the reasons he gave). Plus his reaction to Spike would have been hilarious.He also would have cleared up other issues the show deals with that were somewhat less than exciting: Buffy's trouble with bills, money, loans, counsellors, Dawn, schooling and so on. Buffy flipping burgers for money didn't exactly make for riveting T.V. and by exploring these real-life situations the writers bring up several more problems.  For instance, Willow lives in the Summers house, eating Buffy's food, using her hot water, and wasting her electricity, but we never get a mention of is she pays rent or not. For that matter, does Willow even have a job?The characterisation of Buffy is another problem: where is our spunky, brave young heroine? Granted, she would have felt depressed on re-entering earth, but to drag it out for an entire season was as depressing for us as it was for her. I give the writers credit for trying to take the show in a new direction, but let's face it, no one watches a show called "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" with expectations of something too dark. As it was, we dealt with suicide attempts, drug addition, murder, misogyny, theft, lying, betrayal, casual sex, depression, child neglect, and not one but two attempts at rape. To see characters we've known for years and come to care deeply for dragged through such muck is quite distressing to behold - especially as it seems that the writers really have no idea how to deal with the issues that they're raising.Case in point: Tara's mind is magically altered (ie abused) by Willow, and she sensibly distances herself from her violator. By the time reconciliation is reached however, she doesn't want to go over the rebuilding of trust and respect - instead to jump straight to the kissing. Yes, I know it's all fiction, but these are dangerous and series issues to raise, people do have these sort of problems in life, and they can't be brushed under the rug as easily as they are on the show.But it wasn't all bad, and there are a few outstanding moments. The famous musical episode "Once More With Feeling" deserves a place among the top ten Buffy episodes of all time, with catchy songs, extraordinary pathos, some of the funniest lines ever, and the depth of feeling and emotion that only singing can bring out. As well as this, Tara and Anya finally get some personalities that go beyond the droll-and-sarcastic comic-relief and the sweet-but-dull girlfriend. We get some new characters; Hallie, an old acquaintance of Anya's, and Clem the not-so-evil demon. Amy the witch (who has appeared in every single season except season five) finally gets de-ratted, and stirs up some trouble for Willow when she introduces her to some darker magics. Unfortunately, Amy was always a favourite guest-star of mine, and I was bummed to see her end up somewhat evil. I was hoping for redemption, but sadly it doesn't happen. Oh well, at least she was de-ratted. Riley's back for a quick visit, and as always we're treated with a breathtaking finale.Love it or hate it, season six is a necessary part of the ongoing Buffy story, and don't worry - things pick up for the final season.

reviewText: Note:  Insert standard spoiler warning of your choice here!Season Six of BUFFY is the show's most controversial by far.  Sarah Michelle Gellar has stated that she found the mid-season episodes between her and Spike to be degrading and unpleasant and many fans would agree with her.  This was the season that Joss Whedon left the show as the day-to-day show runner and turned over the reins to Marti Noxon, though he nonetheless remained deeply involved with the show, supervising the story arcs and individual episodes, as well as writing and directing several episodes.There is no question that Season Six contained some very memorable moments.  There is also little question that the season had some weak episodes--especially at around the two-thirds mark--as well as some not-very-popular story arcs.  The least popular aspects of the show was the self-destructive tendencies and actions of all the major characters and the lameness of the show's "big bads," the geek threesome known as The Trio.  But in fact, the Big Bad of Season Six is each individual against him or herself.  Buffy, struggling with her inadvertent removal from heaven by Willow, suffers economic difficulties, eventually taking a fast food job, eventually numbing herself with a demeaning sexual relationship with Spike.  Willow becomes more and more addicted to using magic, to the point that it first threatens to destroy her relationships and eventually the world.  Xander, fearful that his impending marriage to Anya cold lead to the same kind of family that he grew up in, leaves Anya a the altar.  Anya, crushed by being deserted by Xander, reverts to being a vengeance demon.  Dawn's kleptomania gets out of control until the others discover her problem.  Giles makes an error by going back to England, imagining that Buffy needs to learn to live on her own.  Only Tara does not engage in self-destructive behavior, but her accidental killing spurs Willow's killing spree at the end of the season.  The season's motto could be:  We have met the enemy and he is us.There are titular villains.  Warren, the robot-constructing geek from Season Five's "I Was Made to Love You," Jonathan, the geek who first appeared in the BUFFY pilot (he was considered for the role of Xander before Nicholas Brendon got the job), and Andrew, whose brother was involved in a flying monkey incident no one seems to remember, team up to take over Sunnydale.  They are uber dorks, obsessed with the whole panoply of comic book culture and Star War action figures.  Though them manage to pull off some stunts, apart from Warren's accidental killing of both his ex-girlfriend and Willow, they are a pretty silly lot.  They are more like perpetual comic relief.  BUFFY was always trying to do new things and I applaud them for doing so (the effort to always be fresh was one of the reasons it was such a great show), but I think it is safe to say that having them as the Big Bads was a bit of a mistake.  In the end, their greatest contribution was in providing victims for Willow's rampage at season's end.  Indeed, the single most horrifying moment in the history of the show had to be the terrible instance in which Willow, after catching and briefly torturing Warren for killing Tara, magically removes his entire epidermis.  Not just on BUFFY, apart from some moments in THE SOPRANOS, I know no more terrible instance in the history of TV.  Clearly they wanted to demonstrate just how far Willow had gone.Although the season's story arcs were not especially satisfying, there were a number of unforgettable episodes.  The season begins with a great sequence of episodes, as Willow with the assistance of Tara, Xander, and Anya raise Buffy, who had died a mystical death at the end of Season Five, from the dead.  Their fear, based largely on Angel's being sent to a hell dimension at the end of Season Two, was that Buffy was suffering unspeakable torture in a different hell dimension.  But we later learn that she was, in fact, in a place of great peace and repose, a place she could only describe as "heaven."  The first six episodes see Buffy struggling to deal with her return to a place that now felt like hell.  All these early episodes, even if not strong all the way through, contain at least some great moments.Then come Episodes 7 and 8, not just the best episodes of the season, but among the best in the run of the show.  "Once More, with Feeling" is often cited as the very best episode of BUFFY, and to those who wish the show had ended at the end of Season Five, my response is always, "Would you really have wanted for there never to have been "Once More, With Feeling?"  This was the musical episode and while many shows have attempted musical episodes, this one stands far above what any other show has either attempted or achieved.  What is amazing is how fine the episode was despite not having a world of musical talent on the show.  Only Anthony Stewart Head (who had taken over the lead in THE ROCKY HORROR PICTURE SHOW in London in the original production and sung on albums by his brother Murray, the original Judas in JESUS CHRIST, SUPERSTAR), James Marsters (who headed his own rock band), and Amber Benson (who played Tara) had especially good voices.  Though not a trained singer, Sarah Michelle Gellar nonetheless acquitted herself quite well both singing and dancing, and Michelle Trachtenberg, though not a singer, put her dance training to good use. Joss Whedon contributed a very fine group of songs.  In one of the best guest appearances in the run of the show, veteran Broadway hoofer Hinton Battle (perhaps best known as the Scarecrow in the entire run of THE WIZ on Broadway) played the demon Sweet, who was accidentally summoned to Sunnydale, and who was responsible for the singing and dancing afflicting everyone.  The most amazing thing about the episode was the way that the songs advanced every story arc in the show and greatly accelerated the action.  The best songs were Buffy's Disneyesque "Going Through the Motions" that started the episode; Tara's singing of "Under Your Spell" to Willow (ironic in that she learned she was literally being controlled by Willow through magic); Spike's passionate expression of his love/hate for Buffy in "Rest in Peace"; the wonderful duet between Tara and Giles; and the great production number that preceded the battle-that-never-occurred with Sweet, "Walk Through the Fire."  Not should also be made of Anya's great bit in an early group number in which the Scoobies are trying to figure out why everyone is singing and dancing.  After singing that she has a theory that it "must be bunnies," the group very ignores her only to have her scream in a great hard rock voice:Bunnies aren't just cute like everybody supposedThey got them hoppy legs and twitchy little nosesAnd what's with all the carrots?What do they need such good eyesight for anyway?Bunnies!  Bunnies!  It must be bunnies!The popularity of the episode can be seen in the fact that it is the only episode to have its script published separately and the soundtrack has been released on compact disc."Once More, with Feeling" was followed by "Tabula Rasa," probably the funniest episode ever on BUFFY.  After Tara catches Willow manipulating their relationship through the use of magic, Willow complicates things by attempting once more to make them all forget that she had used magic to control others.  But the spell misfires and instead everyone in the group, including Willow, forgets who they are.  The scene in which everyone tries to figure out who they are is a classic, the best part being Spike, who has been going about in a dreadful suit as a disguise to escape a loan shark (a demon with literally the head of a shark, the only really awful note in an otherwise stunning episode), deciding that his is Giles's son and that his name is Randy.  When Buffy finds no ID, she tellingly decides that everyone should call her Joan, with echoes of St. Joan in her choice.Unfortunately, while there are few out and out bad episodes, there are few absolutely stunning episodes until the ones that end the season.  The one major exception is "Normal Again," which resembles many of the alternative reality stories of Philip K. Dick.  Buffy is injected with some venom by a demon she fights, and the result is that she imagines that she is actually in a mental institution where she has been fantasizing for several years that she was a vampire slayer in a town called Sunnydale.  Or is reality breaking through to make her cease fantasizing for a while.  We fans, of course, can't imagine that all six seasons were a delusion, but it is nonetheless a brilliant episode.Although I don't believe that this is one of BUFFY's best seasons, I can't give this less than five stars simply because even during this season BUFFY remained one of the most brilliant shows on TV.  Not everything in the season succeeded, but they nevertheless continually strove to produce a special show.  The show took risks; they never played things safe.  The problem with taking risks is that sometimes things don't work out.  Still, all in all this was a season with more to delight over than to regret.
summary: BUFFY's most controversial and uneven season
